items.title: I can define stress as a psychobiological process
items.what: Stress is a state of physiological and psychological arousal produced by internal or external stressors that are perceived as challenging or exceeding a person's resources to cope. It involves both biological (e.g. hormonal changes) and psychological (e.g. perception of threat) components.
items.why: The term 'psychobiological' signals that exam answers about stress should integrate both biological and psychological dimensions rather than treating them separately.
items.example: A student experiencing exam stress has both a physiological response (increased heart rate, sweating due to sympathetic nervous system activation) and a psychological response (anxiety, difficulty concentrating due to perceiving the exam as threatening).

subtopic.name: Stressors and Stress Responses
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the definitions of stress, stressors, eustress, and distress, as well as the distinction between internal and external stressors and the physiological and psychological dimensions of the stress response.
subtopic.why: Understanding these foundational concepts is essential because every other topic in this chapter builds on them. Exam questions frequently test whether students can correctly identify eustress vs distress as responses (not types of stressors) and classify stressors as internal or external.

items.title: I can distinguish between eustress and distress as types of stress responses
items.what: Eustress is a positive stress response characterised by motivation, excitement, and focused energy when a stressor is perceived as manageable. Distress is a negative stress response characterised by anxiety, tension, or helplessness when a stressor is perceived as threatening or overwhelming.
items.why: A common exam error is treating eustress and distress as types of stressors rather than types of responses. The same stressor can produce eustress in one person and distress in another depending on perception.
items.example: A job interview produces eustress in a well-prepared candidate who feels confident (motivation, alertness) but distress in someone who feels underprepared (anxiety, dread). The stressor is the same; the responses differ based on perception.

items.title: I can distinguish between internal and external stressors with examples
items.what: Internal stressors originate within the individual (e.g. negative self-talk, chronic pain, perfectionism). External stressors originate from the environment and range from daily hassles to catastrophes.
items.why: Correctly classifying stressors matters because internal stressors often involve psychological processes while external stressors involve environmental demands, and this distinction connects to how different stress models explain the stress response.
items.example: Internal: a student's belief that 'I always fail at maths' (negative self-talk). External: the 2019-20 Black Summer bushfires (catastrophe), a homework deadline (daily hassle), or moving to a new country and facing language barriers (acculturative stress).

items.title: I can describe physiological and psychological stress responses
items.what: Physiological responses include increased heart rate, blood pressure, sweating, muscle tension, and elevated cortisol and adrenaline. Psychological responses include cognitive effects (difficulty concentrating, racing thoughts), emotional effects (anxiety, irritability), and behavioural effects (withdrawal, procrastination, substance use).
items.why: Exam questions often present a scenario and ask you to identify or explain specific stress responses. Being able to categorise responses as physiological or psychological demonstrates understanding of the psychobiological nature of stress.
items.example: Marcus, caring full-time for his elderly mother for two years, shows physiological responses (frequent colds from immune suppression, high blood pressure) and psychological responses (exhaustion, emotional fatigue, possible withdrawal from social activities).

items.title: I can explain the fight-or-flight response, including the role of the sympathetic nervous system and adrenal medulla
items.what: When the amygdala detects a threat, it signals the hypothalamus, which activates the sympathetic nervous system. The adrenal medulla releases adrenaline and noradrenaline, producing rapid changes: increased heart rate, blood pressure, breathing rate, pupil dilation, sweating, and blood redistribution from digestive organs to skeletal muscles.
items.why: Understanding this pathway is essential for explaining acute stress responses in exam scenarios and for correctly linking biological structures to their functions.
items.example: A hiker encounters a snake on the trail. The amygdala detects the threat, the sympathetic NS activates, the adrenal medulla releases adrenaline, and the hiker's heart races, breathing quickens, and muscles tense — preparing the body to run (flight) or confront the threat (fight).

subtopic.name: Fight-Flight-Freeze and the Biology of Stress
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fight-flight-freeze response, the roles of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, and the critical distinction between acute stress (adrenaline from the adrenal medulla) and chronic stress (cortisol from the adrenal cortex via the HPA axis).
subtopic.why: The biology of stress is heavily tested in exams. The 2023 and 2024 examiners' reports highlighted that students frequently confuse which nervous system division is dominant during freeze, and which hormone and adrenal structure is involved in acute versus chronic stress.

items.title: I can explain the freeze response and identify the parasympathetic nervous system as dominant
items.what: The freeze response occurs when a threat seems overwhelming or inescapable. Unlike fight and flight, the parasympathetic nervous system overrides the sympathetic NS, causing tonic immobility: body movements stop, heart rate decelerates, blood pressure drops, and the person may feel unable to move or speak.
items.why: The 2023 examiners' report noted many students incorrectly identified the sympathetic NS as dominant during freeze. This is a frequently tested distinction worth memorising precisely.
items.example: During an armed robbery, a person freezes — they cannot move, speak, or call for help. Their heart rate drops and muscles become rigid. This is the parasympathetic NS overriding the sympathetic NS, producing tonic immobility rather than the heightened arousal of fight or flight.

subtopic.name: Fight-Flight-Freeze and the Biology of Stress
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fight-flight-freeze response, the roles of the sympathetic and parasympathetic nervous systems, and the critical distinction between acute stress (adrenaline from the adrenal medulla) and chronic stress (cortisol from the adrenal cortex via the HPA axis).
subtopic.why: The biology of stress is heavily tested in exams. The 2023 and 2024 examiners' reports highlighted that students frequently confuse which nervous system division is dominant during freeze, and which hormone and adrenal structure is involved in acute versus chronic stress.

items.title: I can distinguish between the role of the adrenal medulla in acute stress and the adrenal cortex in chronic stress
items.what: The adrenal medulla (inner part of the adrenal gland) releases adrenaline during acute, short-term stress via the sympathetic NS. The adrenal cortex (outer layer) releases cortisol during chronic, long-term stress via the HPA axis (hypothalamus releases CRH, pituitary releases ACTH, adrenal cortex releases cortisol).
items.why: In 2024, students confused cortisol depletion with adrenaline depletion when answering questions about the exhaustion stage of GAS. Using the correct hormone and adrenal structure for the correct stress context is critical for earning marks.
items.example: Acute stress: nearly avoiding a car accident triggers adrenaline release from the adrenal medulla, causing a brief spike in heart rate and alertness. Chronic stress: months of workplace bullying triggers sustained cortisol release from the adrenal cortex via the HPA axis, eventually leading to immune suppression and fatigue.

items.title: I can describe the harmful effects of prolonged cortisol exposure
items.what: While cortisol is adaptive in the short term (maintaining energy and function), prolonged exposure from chronic stress causes hypertension, hippocampal shrinkage (impairing memory), weakened immune function, disrupted sleep, increased vulnerability to anxiety and depression, and weight gain.
items.why: Understanding the harmful effects of chronic cortisol exposure connects the biology of stress to the exhaustion stage of GAS and to real-world health outcomes that appear in exam scenarios.
items.example: A nurse working excessive overtime for a year develops high blood pressure (hypertension from sustained cortisol), catches frequent colds (immune suppression from cortisol), and notices worsening memory (hippocampal shrinkage from prolonged cortisol exposure).

items.title: I can describe the gut-brain axis as a bidirectional communication link
items.what: The gut-brain axis is a bidirectional communication system between the brain and the gastrointestinal tract. Signals travel in both directions: the brain influences the gut (e.g. stress alters gut microbiota via cortisol), and the gut influences the brain (e.g. gut bacteria produce neurotransmitters that affect mood).
items.why: The word 'bidirectional' is key to answering GBA questions correctly. Many students only describe one direction of communication and lose marks.
items.example: Bidirectional: Chronic exam stress (brain to gut) increases cortisol, which reduces the diversity of gut microbiota. In turn, the disrupted gut microbiota (gut to brain) reduces serotonin production, worsening the student's mood and anxiety.

subtopic.name: The Gut-Brain Axis
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the bidirectional communication link between the brain and gastrointestinal tract, including the role of the vagus nerve, gut microbiota, and the enteric nervous system, and why the VCAA describes it as an area of emerging research.
subtopic.why: The GBA is a flagship topic of the 2023-2027 study design. It was the focus of the 10-mark extended response in 2023 and appeared in short-answer questions in 2024. Understanding the key mechanisms and research evidence is essential for high-scoring exam responses.

items.title: I can explain the role of the vagus nerve in the gut-brain axis
items.what: The vagus nerve is the longest cranial nerve and the primary neural link between the gut and brain. Approximately 80-90% of its fibres are afferent (carrying information from the gut to the brain), while only 10-20% are efferent (brain to gut). This means the gut sends far more information to the brain than vice versa.
items.why: The predominantly afferent nature of the vagus nerve is a commonly tested detail. Bravo et al. (2011) showed that cutting the vagus nerve eliminated the stress-reducing effects of a probiotic in mice, confirming the vagus nerve as the key communication pathway.
items.example: Bravo et al. (2011): Mice fed Lactobacillus rhamnosus showed reduced anxiety and altered GABA receptor expression in the brain. When the vagus nerve was severed, these benefits disappeared entirely — demonstrating that gut bacteria influence the brain specifically through the vagus nerve.

items.title: I can describe how gut microbiota influence stress and neurotransmitter production
items.what: Gut microbiota are the trillions of microorganisms in the GI tract. A diverse and balanced microbiota is associated with reduced stress reactivity, while dysbiosis (microbial imbalance) is linked to increased anxiety and depression. Gut microbiota produce approximately 95% of the body's serotonin, as well as GABA and dopamine.
items.why: Understanding that gut bacteria produce neurotransmitters links the GBA to the broader nervous system content in Unit 3 and provides the biological mechanism for how diet and gut health can influence mental wellbeing.
items.example: Sudo et al. (2004): Germ-free mice (with no gut bacteria) showed exaggerated HPA stress responses — significantly more cortisol when stressed. When colonised with Bifidobacterium infantis, their stress response normalised, showing gut microbiota are essential for normal stress regulation.

items.title: I can explain why the GBA is described as an area of emerging research
items.what: The GBA is described as emerging research because the field is relatively new, many studies rely on animal models (raising questions about generalisability to humans), the precise mechanisms are still being mapped, and interventions like probiotics for mental health have not yet been conclusively validated in large-scale human trials.
items.why: Acknowledging the limitations of current GBA research shows evaluative thinking, which earns marks in extended responses. Students who present GBA findings as established fact without noting limitations miss the nuance the VCAA expects.
items.example: While Sudo et al. (2004) and Bravo et al. (2011) provide compelling evidence that gut microbiota influence stress, both studies used mice. Whether the same mechanisms operate identically in humans with more complex cognitive processes and diverse diets is still being investigated.

items.title: I can describe the three stages of GAS including the sub-phases of the alarm reaction
items.what: Stage 1 (Alarm Reaction) has two sub-phases: shock (resistance drops below normal, brief loss of preparedness) and counter-shock (sympathetic NS activates, adrenaline released, resistance rises above normal). Stage 2 (Resistance) involves sustained arousal above normal via cortisol release from the adrenal cortex. Stage 3 (Exhaustion) occurs when bodily resources are depleted and resistance falls below normal.
items.why: Being able to accurately describe all three stages and their physiological mechanisms is the foundation for applying GAS to exam scenarios. The shock and counter-shock sub-phases are often overlooked but do appear in exam questions.
items.example: A teacher faces ongoing conflict with administration for months. Alarm: initial shock when first confronted, then counter-shock as adrenaline surges and she prepares to respond. Resistance: she copes for weeks, cortisol sustaining her through elevated arousal. Exhaustion: after months, she develops chronic fatigue, frequent illness, and high blood pressure as resources deplete.

subtopic.name: Selye's General Adaptation Syndrome
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Selye's three-stage biological model of the body's response to stress (alarm reaction with shock and counter-shock, resistance, exhaustion), the non-specificity principle, and how to evaluate the model's explanatory power including strengths and limitations.
subtopic.why: GAS is one of two core stress models in the study design. The VCAA repeatedly emphasises the need to evaluate explanatory power — not just describe the stages — and students who only describe the model without making evaluative judgements consistently lose marks.

items.title: I can draw and interpret the standard GAS graph
items.what: The GAS graph has Time on the x-axis, Level of Resistance to Stress on the y-axis, and a horizontal dashed line representing normal resistance. The curve shows a characteristic pattern: dip below normal (shock), sharp rise above normal (counter-shock), plateau above normal (resistance), then decline below normal (exhaustion).
items.why: Exam questions may ask you to draw, label, or interpret the graph. Understanding the shape of the curve helps you connect each stage to the physiological mechanisms occurring at that point.
items.example: During the resistance stage, the graph shows resistance plateauing above normal — this corresponds to sustained cortisol release from the adrenal cortex keeping the body functioning under ongoing stress, while non-essential processes like immune function are suppressed.

items.title: I can explain the non-specificity principle of GAS
items.what: The non-specificity principle states that the body responds to all stressors with the same general physiological pattern, regardless of whether the stressor is physical (cold, injury) or psychological (exam pressure, conflict). Selye demonstrated this by exposing rats to varied stressors and observing the same triad: enlarged adrenal cortex, shrunken thymus/lymph nodes, and stomach ulcers.
items.why: Non-specificity explains why very different stressors (physical injury, emotional trauma) can produce similar health outcomes (hypertension, ulcers). It also reveals a limitation: GAS cannot account for why people respond differently to the same stressor.
items.example: A soldier in combat (physical danger) and an accountant during tax season (psychological pressure) may both develop high blood pressure and weakened immunity — GAS explains this through the non-specificity principle: the body's biological stress response is the same regardless of the stressor.

items.title: I can evaluate the strengths of GAS as a biological model of stress
items.what: GAS strengths include: it was the first model to systematically link chronic stress to disease; it provides rich physiological detail with measurable biological mechanisms; it has strong laboratory evidence with replicable results; and it explains how different stressors produce similar physical outcomes (non-specificity).
items.why: Evaluation questions require you to make a judgement about the model's explanatory power, not just list features. Knowing the strengths allows you to explain what GAS can account for in a given scenario.
items.example: GAS has strong explanatory power for Mei's workplace burnout: her chronic 60-hour weeks have persisted for months, and her symptoms (exhaustion, frequent colds, high blood pressure) are consistent with the exhaustion stage, where prolonged cortisol exposure depletes resources and suppresses immune function.

items.title: I can evaluate the limitations of GAS as a biological model of stress
items.what: GAS limitations include: it ignores individual differences (assumes everyone responds identically); it ignores psychological factors like cognitive appraisal; it is based primarily on animal research (rats); it assumes linear progression through stages; and it cannot explain eustress or positive stress responses.
items.why: Understanding limitations is essential for evaluation questions, especially those asking why GAS cannot explain a particular scenario. The inability to account for individual differences is the most frequently tested limitation.
items.example: GAS has poor explanatory power for why Aisha feels motivated and Ben feels overwhelmed about the same exam. GAS predicts the same biological response for both students and cannot account for this individual variation because it does not include cognitive appraisal or psychological factors.

items.title: I can describe primary appraisal and its three possible outcomes
items.what: Primary appraisal is a person's initial evaluation of a situation's significance — 'What does this mean for me?' There are three possible outcomes: irrelevant (no relevance to wellbeing), benign-positive (perceived as favourable), or stressful. Stressful appraisals are further categorised as harm/loss (damage already occurred), threat (potential future harm), or challenge (potential for growth).
items.why: Correctly identifying the type of primary appraisal in a scenario is essential for applying the model in exam questions. The distinction between threat and challenge appraisals directly explains why some people experience distress and others experience eustress.
items.example: Anya receives news of potential redundancy and appraises it as a threat (potential loss of income, career setback) — triggering anxiety. David appraises the same news as a challenge (opportunity to find a better role) — triggering motivated action. Same stressor, different primary appraisals.

subtopic.name: Lazarus and Folkman's Transactional Model
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Lazarus and Folkman's psychological model of stress, including primary appraisal (irrelevant, benign-positive, stressful with harm/loss, threat, challenge) and secondary appraisal (evaluation of coping resources), and how to evaluate the model's explanatory power.
subtopic.why: The Transactional Model is the psychological counterpart to GAS. It is central to explaining individual differences in stress responses. The 2023 exam question on nightmares (74% scored zero) showed that students struggle to evaluate when this model does not apply — understanding its limitations is as important as understanding its content.

items.title: I can describe secondary appraisal and its role in determining the stress response
items.what: Secondary appraisal is the person's evaluation of their coping resources and options — 'What can I do about this?' They assess internal resources (confidence, skills, experience) and external resources (money, time, social support). If resources are judged sufficient, the stress response is minimal; if demands greatly exceed resources, significant stress occurs.
items.why: Secondary appraisal explains why two people who both appraise a situation as threatening can still differ in their stress responses — one may feel they have the resources to cope, while the other does not.
items.example: Two students both appraise a VCE exam as a threat. Student A evaluates her resources: strong study notes, teacher support, past exam experience — and feels manageable stress. Student B evaluates his resources: poor preparation, no study group, limited time — and feels overwhelming distress.

subtopic.name: Lazarus and Folkman's Transactional Model
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers Lazarus and Folkman's psychological model of stress, including primary appraisal (irrelevant, benign-positive, stressful with harm/loss, threat, challenge) and secondary appraisal (evaluation of coping resources), and how to evaluate the model's explanatory power.
subtopic.why: The Transactional Model is the psychological counterpart to GAS. It is central to explaining individual differences in stress responses. The 2023 exam question on nightmares (74% scored zero) showed that students struggle to evaluate when this model does not apply — understanding its limitations is as important as understanding its content.

items.title: I can evaluate the strengths of the Transactional Model
items.what: Strengths include: it explains individual differences in stress responses (its central feature); it focuses on controllable factors that can be modified through interventions like CBT; it is based on human research (unlike GAS); and it has led to effective evidence-based stress management approaches.
items.why: Knowing when the Transactional Model has strong explanatory power allows you to select it as the more appropriate model in exam scenarios involving individual variation or differing perceptions of the same stressor.
items.example: The Transactional Model has strong explanatory power for why Aisha (motivated) and Ben (overwhelmed) respond differently to the same exam. Aisha appraises it as a challenge and evaluates her resources as sufficient; Ben appraises it as a threat and evaluates his resources as insufficient.

items.title: I can evaluate the limitations of the Transactional Model
items.what: Limitations include: it cannot explain stress that occurs without conscious appraisal (nightmares, startle responses, infant stress); it overlooks physiological mechanisms (cortisol, immune suppression); appraisal is subjective and difficult to measure experimentally; and it assumes primary appraisal precedes secondary appraisal, when they often occur simultaneously.
items.why: The 2023 nightmare question (74% scored zero) tested this directly. Students described what appraisal would look like in a nightmare rather than recognising the model cannot explain unconscious stress. Understanding when the model fails is critical for evaluation.
items.example: The Transactional Model has poor explanatory power for Selena's nightmare (racing heart, sweating while asleep). She is asleep and unable to engage in conscious cognitive appraisal. Her symptoms are involuntary physiological responses controlled by the autonomic NS, which this psychological model does not address.

The 2023 exam question on nightmares (74% scored zero) showed that students struggle to evaluate when this model does not apply — understanding its limitations is as important as understanding its content.

items.title: I can compare GAS and the Transactional Model across scenarios
items.what: GAS uses biological language (cortisol, adrenaline, alarm/resistance/exhaustion) and explains universal physiological responses to chronic stress. The Transactional Model uses psychological language (appraisal, perceived threat, coping resources) and explains individual differences. Each model has strong explanatory power for different types of scenarios.
items.why: Exam questions frequently require comparison, and examiners penalise students who mix biological language with the psychological model or vice versa. In 2023, only 38% correctly answered a multiple-choice question because distractors used mismatched model language.
items.example: Workplace burnout with physical symptoms (fatigue, illness, hypertension): GAS is stronger — it explains how chronic cortisol depletes resources. Two people responding differently to the same stressor: the Transactional Model is stronger — it explains how different appraisals produce different responses. Nightmares: neither model is ideal, but fight-flight-freeze provides the best explanation.

items.title: I can distinguish between approach and avoidance coping strategies with examples
items.what: Approach coping strategies directly confront or address the stressor (e.g. seeking advice, problem-solving, creating an action plan). Avoidance coping strategies evade, minimise, or disengage from the stressor (e.g. denial, distraction, procrastination, substance use).
items.why: A common exam misconception is that avoidance coping is always maladaptive. In fact, avoidance can be appropriate when the stressor is uncontrollable. Understanding this nuance prevents lost marks.
items.example: Approach: a student struggling with physics creates a study plan and books a tutoring session. Avoidance: a patient awaiting medical test results watches a movie to distract themselves from worrying — this is appropriate because they cannot influence the results.

subtopic.name: Coping Strategies and Flexibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the distinction between approach and avoidance coping strategies, the principle of context-specific effectiveness, and the concept of coping flexibility including its three components (awareness, discontinuation, replacement).
subtopic.why: Coping flexibility was tested in 2024 with only 1% of students scoring full marks. Understanding that no coping strategy is universally good or bad — and that flexibility involves knowing when to switch — is essential for high-scoring responses.

items.title: I can explain the principle of context-specific effectiveness of coping strategies
items.what: Context-specific effectiveness means a coping strategy's appropriateness depends on the match between the strategy and the situation. Approach strategies are generally more effective for controllable stressors; avoidance strategies may be more appropriate for uncontrollable stressors. However, excessive long-term reliance on avoidance is associated with poorer mental health.
items.why: This principle prevents oversimplified judgements about coping. Exam questions may present a scenario where avoidance is the better choice, and students who rigidly label all avoidance as negative will lose marks.
items.example: Controllable stressor: failing a practice exam — approach coping (revising weak areas) is more effective than avoidance. Uncontrollable stressor: grieving the death of a loved one — some avoidance (distraction, temporary emotional disengagement) may be more appropriate than constantly trying to 'solve' grief.

subtopic.name: Coping Strategies and Flexibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the distinction between approach and avoidance coping strategies, the principle of context-specific effectiveness, and the concept of coping flexibility including its three components (awareness, discontinuation, replacement).
subtopic.why: Coping flexibility was tested in 2024 with only 1% of students scoring full marks. Understanding that no coping strategy is universally good or bad — and that flexibility involves knowing when to switch — is essential for high-scoring responses.

items.title: I can define coping flexibility and describe its three components
items.what: Coping flexibility is the ability to modify, adjust, or switch coping strategies based on changing situational demands. It involves three components: awareness (recognising the current strategy is ineffective), discontinuation (stopping the ineffective strategy), and replacement (implementing a different, more suitable strategy). High coping flexibility is associated with better mental health outcomes.
items.why: Coping flexibility was the focus of the 2024 question where only 1% scored full marks. Understanding the three components and being able to identify them in a scenario is essential.
items.example: Jamil initially copes with exam stress using a detailed timetable (approach). After two weeks he recognises it is not working (awareness), abandons the timetable (discontinuation), and switches to practising past exam papers (replacement). This demonstrates high coping flexibility and improves his confidence and control.

subtopic.name: Coping Strategies and Flexibility
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the distinction between approach and avoidance coping strategies, the principle of context-specific effectiveness, and the concept of coping flexibility including its three components (awareness, discontinuation, replacement).
subtopic.why: Coping flexibility was tested in 2024 with only 1% of students scoring full marks. Understanding that no coping strategy is universally good or bad — and that flexibility involves knowing when to switch — is essential for high-scoring responses.

items.title: I can evaluate the relationship between coping flexibility and other concepts
items.what: Evaluating coping flexibility in relation to other concepts requires analysing whether the other concept supports or constrains the ability to switch strategies. For example, mindfulness meditation emphasises sustained, non-judgemental acceptance — committing to a single consistent approach — which may limit the flexibility to abandon and switch strategies.
items.why: The 2024 exam question about coping flexibility and mindfulness (1% full marks, 43% scored zero) required students to identify the tension between a fixed approach (mindfulness) and the adaptive switching that defines coping flexibility.
items.example: Mindfulness as a sole coping strategy may reduce coping flexibility because it commits to sustained acceptance rather than switching approaches. However, mindfulness as one tool within a broader coping repertoire supports flexibility — the person can use mindfulness sometimes and switch to problem-solving or social support when more appropriate.
